prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Underpass-Echo

When dusk went drumble and the road did swoon,
And gutter-glints went plinkle-ploon,
The lamp-post yawned a sleepy chim,
And sidewalks feathered soft and dim.

Beware the underpass-echo, my friend,
The drowse that snatches words and bends;
It snorfles speech in brumpled loops,
And flings it back in wobble-troops.

He crept with clump of clatter-shoe,
Past brick-bloom arch and dripstone blue;
The tunnel mouthed a gumble-greet,
A hollow-hum with slippered feet.

"Halloo!" he cried — the echo grinned,
It snipped his shout and spangly-spinned;
"Hulloo!" it jibbered, "Hullo-ha!"
A tumble-tift of mirror-maw.

It gobbled names and stitched them new,
With twistle-tongues of silverdew;
His "friend" became a flitter-fend,
His "home" a hummed and huddle-blend.

It snick-sneezed laughs in cobble-tones,
And rattled secrets into bones;
A shoal of answers, slim and sly,
Swam backward through the archway's eye.

So tread the underpass with care,
Lest echo-tailers snatch your air;
They craft small ghosts of what you say,
And pirouette your truth away.

He left with pockets full of hush,
While echoes went on snook and rush;
They ripple on, in twilight's keep,
Where underpasses mumble and sleep.
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Twas fog-gleam at dawn, and the sooth-slime crept
Across the lea where the drowsy reeds slept;
The glim-shade twined with a whispery hiss,
And dirk-wet petals drank the mist.

Beware the Murkling, my child, beware
Its blunder-breath and its coal-soft glare;
It skiffs the path with a slubbered tread,
And tangles the sun in a feathered thread.

It whumpers past on blanket-hush feet,
Its eye a smudge of midnight meat;
But High-gleam, armed with a sun-spear bright,
Pricked the pall with a splinter of light.

The fog unrolled like a yawning scroll,
A paper-sea with an inked black hole;
Then, snicked and sighed, it loosened its seam,
And gave to the grasses a silver gleam.

So danced the dawn with a blink and a bloom,
Shaking the last of the shadowed gloom;
Yet mind the morn when the air grows thin—
The fog will noodle and slink back in.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Deja-Vuwhiff

’Twas gloaming, and the slivver toves
Did plink and plash in brumpled rue;
All mimsy-quick the night-jar hoves,
And shadow-threads unglue.

Beware the deja-vuwhiff, my child!
The look that loops and hems the seam;
Beware the pre-remembered wild
That drifts along the dream!

He snatched his glim-sabre, bright and thin,
And sought the twice-trod fen and lane;
O’er echo-stone and mirror-skin
He followed faint refrain.

The deja-vuwhiff! It winked in twain,
Its grin a twice-seen, fraying grin;
It hummed the joke he’d told ere plain,
Then curled and whispered in.

With flench and briz the loophold snapped,
The looping air unspooled, unspun;
He blinked — the same-day unwrapped —
Yet wondered if ’twas done.

So home he walked through sameborn trees,
Past silver-doors that softly muse;
Each footstep murmured, soft as breeze,
“Haven’t we trod this route—amuse?”
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Desire-Path

'Twas duskle, and the hedgle-thrum did swing,
And shadow-winks crept soft on knoll and stream;
When first I spied the slyly-silvering thing—
A crooked winktrap of a willful dream.

"Beware the Desire-Path," my neighbour cried,
"That sneaks betwixt the hedges, skims the lawn;
It whisper-crumbs where reason once did ride,
And nicks the map till careful rules are gone."

But oh! the path did gleam with footsong sweet,
A twine of prints like secrets in the loam;
It stitched the green where pavement feared to meet,
And beckoned boots from every weary home.

With flitter-step I followed, heart aflush,
Past fencelet, signpost, formal-lined parade;
The grass-bell bowed, the tufts did curly-brush,
As longing-lanes in moonlight were displayed.

No monster there, no snarling cart or grawl,
Only the soft, persuasive tread of need;
A murmurous trail that makes the byways fall
And lets a thousand solitary feet be freed.

So fork and tumble, cunning as a sigh,
The Desire-Path will weave your course anew;
It learns your shoe, and hums the reason why—
That crooked ways can sometimes prove most true.

Tread light, dear walker, mind the nettle-gleam;
For every shortcut keeps a little cost;
Yet when the garden opens like a dream,
The boot-traced map shows what the plan had lost.
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Conferoom

Twas squaffing, and the LED-lamps did blink,
The tabletots did scrolly-scroll and drink;
All boardlings bustled in swivelly bloom,
Mugs clanked and hummed about the confer-room.

Beware the Zoomblotch, my team! Beware the Slide!
Beware the Powerwhirr with bullet-barbed stride!
Beware the loquax that long-ramble sings,
The Tempsnore, the gantt that gnaws and clings.

He took his stylus—tap-twang in his palm,
And steeled his notes with marginary calm;
He paced past ficus-guard and credenza-crypt,
Into the glare where projectors snipt.

From cupboard-nook there sprung a Flipchart-beast,
All sticky-note and pie-slice, jargon-feast;
It hissed in bullets, swelled in clip-and-play,
Its graphs did gnash the minutes of the day.

One, two! One, two! His pointer whirled;
He lanced the slide, the decks were furled;
The Zoomblotch shrieked its buzzword-song,
The Powerwhirr unspooled and spluttered long.

The minutes nodded, actions ticked and sealed,
The coffee cooled; the murmurs were repealed;
O frabgle hour! The ledger left its gloom—
And home they trod from brightened confer-room.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about music room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Clefthrum Room

’Twas brum and blink within the door, and fretstrings twanged and swung,
The lamp-clocks ticked in minor keys, the metronome-birds sung;
All squeeved the bow-boards, plonk and puff, the cymblenuts did croon,
While shadows licked the parquet floor in the odd Clefthrum room.

“Beware the Chordelwisp, my bairn, the Snare-snar with hollow drum,
The Tromgrain’s jaws that gulch and grr, the Fipplewump that strum;
Not all the notes are kindly-bent, some smirk in twisted tune—
O mind the hush, the echo-twitch, in the crooked music room.”

He took his baton-gleam, head high, his tailcoat flapped with lace,
A lyreknife twanged within his hand, a pocketed pizzicato mace;
He tiptoed by the harping vines, past basswood’s rumble-bloom,
To where the pitchspawn nosed and curled in the heart of the music room.

There slithered low the Chordelwisp, all fret-teeth, gliss and grope,
Its scale-fins flashed, a serried swarm of broken hope and hope;
It whaffled notes like spilled marbles, it swonged the air with doom,
But he gave a cleaving cadence-shout and struck the steady boom.

He jabbed the lyreknife, pluck-plough, and swung the baton bright,
The Snare-snar yelped its ragged rim, the Tromgrain fell to night;
With one last plink, a silver ring, the Fipplewump was mute,
And all the racks of restless sound lay hushed and resolute.

He bore a ribboned harmony, its head like bell and plume,
Returned beneath the lamp-clock’s blink—home from the Clefthrum room;
The porch-keys chimed in grateful thirds, the curtains sighed in tune,
And every plank and pane replied to the hero’s bright cocoon.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about map in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Mapperwock

'Twas mappling, and the foldy lanes
Did sliver where the inkle drains;
All cartish were the compass-boughs
And scale-ink swam in glossy soughs.

Beware the Mapperwock, my dear!
The crease-clawed doubt, the falseway leer!
Beware the crumple, curve and crux,
The northish gnarl, the ink-ink flux!

He took his pen and charted stride,
And traced the route by moon-tide glide;
Away he went through paper-brash,
Along the seam and past the sash.

Then sprang the Mapperwock, with map-snout wide,
It unfurled a maze of misleads, snide;
He slashed the fold with steady quill,
And broke the bend that brewed the ill.

"O frabjous map!" the pathways sang,
"The true roads shine, the blindfolds hang!"
He folded up the perilous scroll,
And compass-stars led safe his stroll.

So mind the folds when twilight naps,
And trust not every dotted lapse;
For though the Mapperwock may lay
In glinting glyphs and ink-splayed sway,
A careful hand and honest chart
Will guide the wanderer home at heart.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on layover bay in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Layover Bay

Mid-gleam the layover-bay did sprawl,
with shimmergates and tannery squall;
the fleeping lights went blink and sway,
and trolley-gulls cried nork all day.
Baggrove whispers, time-tile creaks,
and announcements drib like peppermint leaks;
where flitterfolk in lounge-suits lay
to dream the drift of moth-checked day.

Beware the Delaywock that skims the piers,
with clatterjaw and suitcase-spears;
it looms in fog of late-call steam,
and snicks your boarding like a seam.
Mind the Snarl on Gate Nine's lip,
the snaggle-queues that backward slip;
lest you be caught in tarry-twine
and miss the moonlit onward line.

But lo! A roving skipper strode,
with boarding-sabre, snack-bag stowed;
he hummed a brabble, clipped the fray,
and cut the Delaywock away.
The trolleys clapped their rubber-flaps,
the screens unspooled their silver maps;
and travelers rose with pocket-sighs
to chase their flights across the skies.

So linger light in Layover Bay,
where time is sticky, sweet, and grey;
pluck up your ticket, tote your ray,
and laugh the gloam-tide's tangling fray.
For though the snatches twist and stay,
the next bright gate will swing your way —
and wings will whisk the wanders free
from lull of lounge and layover sea.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about screen burn‑in in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Burnwock

Twas glimsome eve in pixelglow, and screens did hum and sheen;
The taskbar blinked its ember-bloom, the icons sat between.
Beware the Burnwock, ward your gaze! the old sage softly cried,
For in the hush the statis-ghosts upon your panes abide.

The Burnwock prowls the oled-wood with sticky, lingering grin,
Its watchface grin and nav-badge eyes forever etched within;
It sips the static, saps the hue, leaves phantom clocks that stay,
A faint, faint smile of yesterday that will not fade away.

He took his squeege-sword of code, he raised the smoothing shield,
And ran the pixel-sweep and swipe across the haunted field;
The Burnwock hissed in afterglow, its pixels smeared and thin,
Yet stubborn glyphs in corners clung like barnacled chagrin.

"Engage the saver, roam and shift," the village cursors urged,
"Let moving images parade, let shifting colors surge;
Dim, sleep, rotate, and morph your view — unfix the frozen scene,
So lingered marks, like emberflesh, may loosen, blur, and wean."

With swish and scrub and dith’ring song the brave-screen battled on,
It shuffled panes, it dimmed the blaze, it put the static gone;
At last that lingering Burnwock flamed and scattered into dew —
No more did clock-face haunt the night, no ghosted icons rue.

Oh, heed the counsel, gentle hands, keep motion in thy frame:
Let not thy homescreen sit and set like fossilized a name;
For where the Burnwock once might creep and carve a lasting scar,
A roaming saver, soft and slow, will keep your colors far.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about Monte Carlo in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Monte-Carlo Snickerwheel

Twas moonspun on the cliffish quay,
and glimsy yachts did glurk and sway;
The chip-tide clinked in velvet palms,
and croupy-men sang glimbar psalms.

Beware the Rouletteth, my dear,
the spin-snout sly, the glimmer-ear;
Beware the Slotstomp's clanky jaw,
and shun the Hushcroup's hush-clapped maw.

He took his brillo-chips so bright,
and strode through palm-gleam, dusk and light;
With cashrum badge and nervy grin
he sought the wheel of whorl and spin.

The Rouletteth whirled its spindled eye,
it clacked and clicked and tickled nigh;
He flung his fich, he called "All-in!"
and stopped the whorl with one small din.

Then clatter-bells and shimmer-chimes
did fribble forth in glinting rimes;
The yachtsmiles blinked, the croupy-men
did dance a sly serendiplen.

"O frabjous chip!" the crowd did sing,
"O snick and snag, thou gambled king!"
And on the quay the moonlips peered —
the Monte-mirth had reappeared.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on stage wings in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Wingwight

’Twas scrim-slap dusk, and the backflits swung,
And cue-clocks purrbled low;
All props were tuckered, the ropes hummed young,
By wings where whisp-ales blow.

Beware the Wingwight, O marshall-eye,
With tassel-teeth and twiney hand;
He snips the stitch of a line-off-cry
And muddles the footwork’s stand.

He hides in riggle-rooms, all pin-scarred and slack,
Where gobble-gels of dust congeal;
He munches cue-sheets with a paper-crack,
And snares the footlights’ zeal.

So forth I crept with a cue-knife bright,
Through fluffle-frames and shadow-glush;
Past spangle-motes and the rope-mouse’s flight,
Through the smell of varnish-brush.

There squatted the Wingwight on a gaffer-crest,
His eye a single bulb aglow;
He snare-tossed my flats with a clatter-snest,
And hummed a backstage woe.

I swung my cue, a flaggle-spear,
And clapped the wings with a click;
He slumped in a frump of silken-gear,
All tangle-thin and quick.

Back to the boards with the scarf I bore,
The shout of scene-doors rang;
Now props breathe free and the cables snore,
And the house-lights softly sang.

O hush, young player, when wings go dim —
Lock pin, hush ropes, and sing;
Yet mind the creak and the shadow-grim,
And guard against the Wingwight’s sting.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about brown butter in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brownbutterwock

'Twas brizzle, and the sizzly pans
Did gyre and glimmer on the grate;
All nutsy were the skimméd clots,
And the milk-sprites snuffled late.

"Beware the Brownbutter, my cook!
The bubbles that brown, the flakes that pop!
Beware the Nubbin-crumbs that look
To scorch and spatter, snap and hop!"

He took his spurtle in his hand;
Long time the sizzling foe he sought,
Sooped and stirred through buttery land
Where foamy, toasty vapors wrought.

And as he stirred there came a hiss,
The browning bells went tick and thrum;
One moment pale as clouded bliss —
The next, a nutty-gold became hum.

Out spat the curds with crackle-snack;
He ladled quick, the pan went clack;
He browned, he smelled, he skimmed the tack,
And trimmed the froth with spoony-snap.

"O frabjous drib! O nutty-day!
He brought his brownling home with grin;
The toast-folk cheer, the pancakes sway,
The kitchen hums — the brown has win."

So leave thy pan with patient eye,
Let milk-sprites sing, let gentle heat
Turn pale to bronze and sigh to sky —
And feast upon the brownbutter sweet.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Beware the Creep

’Twas murrowe'en, and the shadow-slink
Did drape the lane in muffled mink;
The snervy boughs with chirplets crept,
And hushlings hore the moonlight wept.

“Beware the Creep, my bairn,” they cried,
“The slythin thing with slubbed-hide;
It slithers soft on velvet noes,
And sips the hush where daylight goes.

Its whiskers twitch with glimmer-glee,
Its knuckled claws tap twig and tree;
It hums in sylls of secret steam,
It nuzzles night into a dream.

Take up thy lamp, thy schnibble-sword,
And flash the noon in shadow’s ford;
For if it finds thee snug and deep,
It steals the knot of all thy sleep.”

So forth I strode with heart aflare,
And fog-petals puffed the breathing air;
I flung a laugh, a flaring peep —
O frindle-bright! I chased the Creep.

The Creep it skirled, it whiffed, it fled,
Its tail a ravel-ruffled thread;
I clipped its whisper, tucked its shade,
And left the lane less glumly made.

Now when the murrowe'en grows thin,
And snervy boughs begin to grin,
We tip our hats and lock our keep,
And softly hum — beware the Creep.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Awl-wock

Twas grimbly, and the snigged skutch
Did prong and pramble in the drave;
All borrowed thrums with stitch and clutch
Were nibbed by knobbled needles brave.

"Beware the Awl-wock, my small!" I cried,
The point that prowls in leathered wood;
Beware its plume of twine and pride,
The pierce that pucks the puckered hood;
Shun the awly, awlful fang
That spangs the seam and spawks the thong!

He took his bradle in his grip —
Long, light, and keen as moonlit nail;
He spied the Awl-wock's silver tip
Besnicked 'mid scraps of sulking scale;
One Jibber-jab! — the leathers cleft,
The Awl-wock twitched and drizzled deft.

"O frabless frap!" the cobbler cried,
"O snatchy stitch and seamer's boon!"
The Awl-wock's tangs fell by his side
Like bristling thorns in serendune.
Calloop! Callimple! The hems were splayed,
The pockets plumped, the hems repaid.

And home he trudged with thready loot,
His satchel full of patch and cheer;
The awl, now quiet, in its root,
Hummed hummed a humble piercing near.
So heed the hum of small, sharp things:
They mend the world with whisper-wings.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about third rail hum in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Third-Rail Hum

Twas thrumble, and the platform-plumes did sway;
The glint-slick trains went snicker-snap and hum;
All mimsy were the ticket-gleams that day,
And fumble-folk with pocket-lights grew numb.

"Beware the Third-Rail Hum, my child!
The buzzle-gleam, the ion-fang that sings;
The glare that grimmles, nights grown sly and wild,
The sparking-snout that shivers under things."

He took his coat of clack and steady stride,
And went whiffling down the stoned concourse-lane;
The hum came hulking, low and wide,
A groan of wire, a jewelled, throbbing vein.

Its thrumble-teeth did shiver glass and bone,
It sloshed electric, purple-sheen and bold;
He did not touch — he sang a hush in tone,
And wrapped the sound in words of wool and gold.

Then all was softer — rail and rumble-thumb
Lay quiet as a tucked-in, dreaming drum;
"O frall," he cried, "the Third-Rail Hum is dumb!"
Zalloo! Zallay! The platform-plumes went numb.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about interference in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Interfret

In the dim-drop of the flickle-hour, where frazzle-wires hum,  
And glinting air-worms tangle the sing-song of the drum,  
Mum's voice, all crinkle, cautions: "Shy the Interfret, my sweet—  
Its fizzing whisk will wobble-wire and muddle every beat."

Oft the signal-sprig did quiver with shush and splotch and skein,  
As nimble noise-nibs nibbled the clear-cloth of the plain;  
So forth with spanner-sabre, bold, the brave small tuner strode,  
Through static-bramble, whir and wob, and fizz-fog's foamy road.

Then came a blorp of blunder-blet, a snarled and splintered sigh,  
A scrunch of cryptic clatter that unbraided sky from sky;  
It bumbled with a jitter-jam, its spokes a zig-zag fret,  
And every whisper-willed to wink as if by mischief met.

"Stand fast!" cried he, the tuner, with wrench and hum-knife bright,  
He twirled the twiddle-knob till hush unknotted from the night;  
With tick of tinct and pluck of plug, with clang and careful cheer,  
He knotted down the Interfret and stilled its noisy sneer.

Now hearth-route hums in honest chords, the netted notes stand free,  
No longer bleat the blunder-buzz nor tangle melody;  
And home he trudged, quite tuneful, with cable-cleansed and set,  
While children clap and radios sing of how he quelled the Interfret.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on umbrella in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Umbrellock

Twas drimmed and swath, and the puddlewights crept,
The sky went slosh with a whispering gray;
All flummoxed were the gutters, and swept
The streetle-blooms in a soggy ballet.

"Beware the Umbrellock, my dear!
The spokes that snap and the ribs that bite;
The crook that curls with a clacking sneer,
And the drip-a-drip of the gloamly night."

He took his brollyblade in gloshing hand,
And whiffling forth through the drizzle-gloom;
He twirled the canopy, round and grand,
Like a moon of oil in the sopping room.

The Umbrellock loomed with a flounceful flap,
Its canopy teeth in a raggle-row spread;
It blustered a blunder, it slugged a slap,
It splinked a spatter across his head.

He slung the brolly and brim-flung wide,
The ribs unrolled with a shoom and cheer;
Rain-beasts scuttered and slipped aside,
As the umbrelling shield shrieked "Begone, from here!"

O glumple-glad was the sogfriend shore,
O swoonful bright the streetle-sun!
He walked, dripless, past puddle and door,
And the Umbrellock hung, all quiet, done.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about science fair in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about film camera in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Shutterwocky

’Twas glimring, and the spindly reels
Did whirr and sprockle in the night;
All silvered glass and velvet seals
Winked glimm’ring frames of argent light.

“Beware the Shutterwock, my son!
The lense that basks in flash and flare;
Beware the Focal-Fang anon,
And shun the Bromidic glare!
For he will click and clip and snap
His sprockets chew the film-bone thin,
And leave thy negatives a-map
Of ghostly grain and halation’s grin.”

He took his bellows-rod in hand;
Long time he paced the darkroom mere;
He set his aperture and planned,
And wound the spool with steady cheer.
Then through the ortho-gloom he went,
Past trays that hissed and fixers sighed,
Till in the murk a shutter bent
And sprocket-grease and moonlight vied.

With silver-fang and mirror-bright
The Shutterwock unfurled its frame;
It bubbled fog and flashed delight,
And cast a thousand phantom claims.
He braced his tripod, made no sound,
He twined a strip of emulsion keen;
With one clean click the world unwound —
Click-tick! — the Shutter’s maw was seen.

O snap! The glass did blink and fall,
The beam unspooled its final spark;
He plucked the lens and, proud and small,
Held up the head against the dark.
Then home he gallumphed, reels aglow,
The negatives in careful fold;
And all the darkroom folk did know
His prints would hang like stories told.

’Twas glimring still, the reels now hush,
The tray-foam calmed, the developer mild;
And sprockets gyred no longer flush,
But held a steady, silvered child.
So heed my word, ye shutter-kin:
Wind slow, expose with patient glee —
Lest you be caught in glass and grin
By Shutterwocks that click and flee.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on printer jam in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Printerwock

Twas blorping in the lit office, and the fuser-gnomes did grind;
All mimsy were the paper-trays, and inklings hummed and wind.
Beware the Printerwock, my chum! the blinking red, the jam!
Beware the spurling sprocket-glee, and shun the paper-clam!

He took his tweezers-thwack in hand; long time the fiend he sought—
So through the tray and overfeed the spool-snarlings he fought.
And as the whir beclunked and clacked, with sproing and gloiling roar,
Came sneezes from the duplex nook and sheets that spouted gore.

One, two! One, two! And through the teeth! The staple-saber sang;
He snicked the hinge, he fluffed the edge, he pulled the ragged gang.
The Printerwock with fuser-smirk, and toner-muzzle black,
Tore half a memo, spageled bold, and left a smudged-backed track.

And as he cleft the paper-beast, the office sang with light:
"O frisk and frabble! O spackle-grin! O callooh, ink so bright!"
The trays unjammed, the rollers run, the blinking ceased its dram—
He brought across the glossy sheet, and quelled the Printerwockan jam.

But hush—behind the copier, a tiny squeak did hum;
For every joyful unjamming births a may-jam yet to come.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about umbrella in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Umbrellawock

'Twas drizzen, and the skitter-sky did sneer,
The puddle-people puddled, plump and small;
All nubble hats were drooped with sog and smear,
And gutter-flues went glorching down the wall.

Beware the Umbrellawock, my child!
With ribbed, ribald spokes and spindled shade,
Its bumbersheen against the gusts runs wild,
A spraffle-flap of brine and blade.

Its canopy was huzzle-hued and broad,
With snapsnatch seams that clinked like tinkered glass;
It shuddered through the wet with snert and nod,
And shook the eaves till gutter-sprites might pass.

He took his paltry peg and clasped it tight,
He flicked the snap that freed the ribby bloom;
The Umbrellawock unfurled—a moon of night—
And whiffling winds began their bluster-boom.

"Come wind, come water, come the sideways rain!"
He cried, and spindling spokes did shing and sing;
The Umbrellawock, with flare and flapper-twain,
Danced bellywise and banished drench and ding.

The wetwrome hissed, the gustsnicks tried to pry,
But spokes of staleframe stood like stubborn oaks;
With one brave twist he twirled it to the sky,
And rainbow-gleams unjangled through the pokes.

O frabjous morn! The puddles plinked with cheer,
The drimble-clouds were shooed to softer light;
He folded up his bumbershoot, held near,
And hummed a dry, delicious, dimpled bite.

So spare a nod to spatter, spray, and squall,
And keep your umbrellawock both close and keen;
For when the sloshy heavens rise and call,
You'll need its ribbed, bright courage to the green.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on map in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Mapwight

’Twas dimling, and the foldy chartle-veil
Did skitter-splash on the brimble-airs;
Ink-snarls twined like gloam-worms in a trail,
And compass-keen sang quirlish cares.

Beware the Mapwight, my little limb!
The crooked crease, the smudge of yore;
His north is not, his south a whim,
His arrows grin and spin and snore.

He lies in rumple-ridges, sly and small,
Where roadle-paths loop snicker-round;
He plucks at pins with a curl-claw’d thrall,
And hides the gulch with a hushypound.

So take thy pointer, spindled true,
And notch the seam with thumb and bone;
Trace the spiring ink that will not rue,
And listen close to the paper’s tone.

With pokesnatch, prickle, and map-gleam bright,
The Mapwight quiv’rung, crumple-shrunk;
Our hero traced through night to light,
What once was blank now spoke and thunk.

Home came he with the chart all cleft,
The folds aglow, the hems unzipped;
No more the Mapwight’s sly theft
Could make their bearing slip or crypt.

Now keep thy fold, lean on its seam,
And mind the ports of wink and warp;
For maps will mottle, maps will dream—
But true hands steer the starry carp.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about film camera in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Shutterwock

Twas glimring, and the sprocket-greens
Did clatterflute and whir,
All flimsy-films did shadow-scroll
In sproffle-dark and blur;
Beware the Shutterwock, my son!
The Lens that glares and basks!
Beware the Flashy-frump, whose pop
Can fry the timid masks!

He took his tripod—steady-stick,
His barrel-lens gleamed bright;
He wound the film with rattle-wind
And set the fstop right.
Long time he peered through viewfind-gleam
Where glint-ghosts swim and lurk,
And heard the clickle-click of teeth
In sprocket-gloom beshirk.

Then spang! the Shutterwock leapt out
With coat of chrome and gilt,
Its aperture gaped fanglike-black,
Its bellows puffed and spilt;
"Snap on!" cried he, and panned his aim,
He focused, held, and drew—
The world hung still in silver-sheen,
A brizzled, mute tableau.

The Shutterwock did flitter-flash,
It whisked a filament of smoke;
But with a steady hand and lens
He captured light that spoke.
He twanged the shutter-bridge—snick-snap—
The frame did hold its breath,
And down the sprocket-bones rolled grain
Like starlings through the depth.

O frabjous click! He grinned, he wound
The spool with triumph-sway;
Callooh! Callay! the darkroom glowed
When prints the night did lay.
They bath-ed out the silver-dream,
They wash-bleached every fear;
And on the table glimmered back
A world, both weird and clear.

So heed the sprocket-gnome, my son,
And mind your lens and light;
For in the shimmer of the dark
A captured tale takes flight.
Beware the Shutterwock, but know
That patient hands can frame
The blink of beast, the hush of dusk,
And give the gloss a name.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about music room in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Musicroomwock

’Twas plinkful, and the quorned keys
Did glint and glumble in the breeze;
The strimping strings did skrill and skroom,
And cymbel-snaps went thimble-zoom.

“Beware the Diddlewump,” cried Ma,
“The Drumblin beast with brassish jaw;
Beware its clatter, bass and bite,
The clangy-cur and shriek of night.”

He took his bow of whisper-wood,
He cocked a reed, he scrubbed his hood,
And out the closet, through the broom,
Came the Hummage-wretch with marbled boom.

One, two! He plucked a spiraled chord—
He tongued a trumpet, twanged the sword;
The beast did quaver, blink and swoon,
It toppled soft on a tambouroon.

And when the final flutter-thrum
Had stilled the trudging metronome,
The room rang clear with tinkle-tide,
All notes unjumbled, side by side.

“O frabjous tune!” the pipers cry,
The piano-puffs all pouted spry;
’Twas wondly, warm, the music-bloom,
And every nook hummed sweetly—boom.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Déjà-Vuwhif

In glim-gleam gloaming of the inner day,
When brumple thoughts go twistle-swish and skew,
And mem-ble memories in murkly play
Like snicker-snaps of time you thought you knew;
The mind did hum and flitterflame anew —
Beware the sly Déjà-Vuwhif's view!

He ambled by the corrodged lamp of yore,
His shadow clung in echo-step and rhyme;
A whiffling whisper hummed, "You passed this door,"
The lane sang back the footfall two times.
Out slid the Vuwicket, twin-eyed, sublime,
Its grin a loop, its grin a backward time.

"Beware!" cried one small pulse within his chest,
"Beware the snare that wears a friendly face;
It folds the now in patter of the past,
And traps the quick, and keeps them circling space."
He lifted up his dawn-sprung, trembling brace,
To meet the mimic of remembered haste.

They sparred in dallied syllables and beats:
The Vuwif spun déjà threads like cobweb-songs;
Each step he struck returned in twin retreats,
Each word he spoke answered in used-up wrongs.
Til with a sudden blink — all cymbal-clongs! —
He laughed and slipped the knot of worn-out throngs.

O frimble-froth, O glore of fresh new view!
Not every echo's claim is thief or muse;
Sometimes the path repeats to let you through,
To show a piece you've missed in earlier cues.
So greet the whif with careful, merry news —
Sing "Hoorleaf! Hoorah!" — and choose to choose.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about stage wings in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Wingwight

In proscenium gloam the side-wings shloom,
Where velvet-gleams and rope-whim scatter,
The wingwights nest in shadow-bloom,
And curtain-mice in riddles chatter.
They scrim and skoffle the bolted brass,
They thrum the backbeat of door and drum,
With fly-rope tongues that hiss and pass
Through pinhole moons where dim lights come.

Beware the scrim-sneak’s whispering claws,
The prop-gnarl’s creak and the flatsnare’s creak,
Lest step on a step and awaken the gauze
That sighs old plays and lines half-sleek.
A hand in a pocket of moth-silk lace
May find a cue-card, bent and bright,
Or meet with a mask with a grinlike face
And bow with a breath in the wingwight’s night.

So sidle, my thesp, with heel on hush,
Let footfall be feather, let hush be hymn;
For wings are the limen where actors brush
The hush of the world and the glare grown dim.
Return through the ragfold with costume and ring —
Bring back your sound from the hush and light —
And tell of the wingwight’s silent thing
That keeps the play between day and night.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about brown butter in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brownbutterwock

Twas sizzletime in the skillet-lands, and popple-crumbs were shy;
The spattlefronds in flour-haze did wobble-sprint and sigh.
All butter-bulbs went fluttish-brim, and milkish solids whirred,
As nic-nut scents outsnuffled air and made the kitchenird.

"Beware the Scorchwock, fryling fiend! The Chargrunt in the foam!
Beware the Slubber-Black that clings and turns the toast to gloam!"
He took his spatulash in hand; he watched the bubbles bloom;
He kept his whisker-eye alight to vanquish smokey gloom.

The butter sang, a goldened swill, then winked a nutty gleam;
Foam frothed, then fewer, then the solids browned to dream.
A brownly, bruni, beurre-noisette glow did creep and crow,
Like chestnut suns on pan-sand dunes, all mordant, warm, and slow.

The Scorchwock lunged with crackle-cry, a hiss of blackened spite;
But steady stir and gentle low saved butter’s amber light.
He tilted back the saucy song, he plucked the pan from heat,
And drizzled, blessed, the toasty drip on cakes of crumb and wheat.

O fragrant-frabbed and nutful-true! O sizzle-sage delight!
From sponk to spoon the brown-butter blooms, a beaky, burly bite.
Call glower-glow and spoonish cheer — the kitchenflock proclaim:
"Long live the browning brave and bold, that zests our crumbs with flame!"
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on interference in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Interfrow

Twas wirling, and the freckle-wires
Did crumple in the gloam;
All flitter-specks and peepish choirs
Were snuffling through the home;
Beware the Interfrow, my dear!
The clashling, burble-noise!
Beware the fuddling, phantom smear
And all its crackle-ploys!

He took his frum-sword, Whisksnap keen;
Long time the static sought;
So rested he by Glinting Screen
And dreamt of quieter thought.
And as in hush of midnight-bloom,
Came shudderstep and fray —
The Interfrow with bumble-boom
And echo-scrape of gray.

One, two! The sputter-blades went snick,
He spang'd the hiss and rout;
He cleft the jangly, jitter-slick,
And flung the fuzzy doubt.
"O huzza!" cried all the clearmucks,
Their channels ringing true;
The wires unknotted, sing-song struck,
And signals sailed anew.

Twas wirling, and the freckle-wires
Did gleam beneath the moon;
All flitter-specks and peepish choirs
Now hummed a steady tune;
Yet heed the whispering, wavering snare —
For every peaceful sphere,
Lurks low the sly, returning glare:
Interference may reappear.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about creep in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Creep

When gloam-sheen crept the bramble-plain and mizzle-moons hung low,
The wimple-bogs did jutter-sway and spatchbones shivered slow;
The twiggle-birds went flemmy-flute and snorl-fern tossed its head,
For in the hush, on tatty-hush, the Creep slid out of bed.

Mark now the Creep with crindle eyes and hairs of cloying mist,
It slithers through the knucklebush with knuckled-knock and hiss;
Its grubber-steps are muffled soft, its chitter-jaws all gleam,
It bargains sighs for knotted dreams and trades your morning's beam.

"Halt, heed!" cried bold young Brimfen-kin, with brimbleblade in hand,
"Keep back, you slunk of gloom and grudge, away from angel-land!"
The Creep did flurry, flang and flit, with spangle-gnash and sneer,
It windled, wharfed, and wimple-snapped and tangled brave with fear.

A zank, a zor, a glitter-skrim — the brimbleblade went true;
It skirred the Creep's cold clew of spite and flung the blackness through;
Down tumbled knuckled-ego lumps and sigh-cloth frayed to rime,
The Creep lay still as cobweb-things, unspun by beat of time.

So sing the twiggle-birds at dusk and sip the fen's soft dew:
Beware the Creep that skulks at heart, in nook and noon and rue;
Yet when you meet its whisper-warp, stand steady, bright, and keep —
For courage cuts the sneering snare and turns aside the Creep.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about awl in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Awlsnarl

’Twas glimble, and the slorping burks
Did trindle in the hide;
All snorfy were the stitch-room clerks,
And frumble-tools were plied.

“Beware the Awlsnarl, my tight-son!
The spur-awl, sharp and sly;
The prong that pricks with sneer and fun,
And makes the leather cry.

“Beware the Spindle-gnash that threads,
The Nicker-needle’s bite;
But most of all the hollow-bleds
That sip the oil by night.”

He took his stout hand-haft, awl in grip,
Long-ish, brastly, keen;
He stalked the stitchway, hip to hip
With shadows stitch-unclean.

And, as he whiffling through the hem,
The Awlsnarl glint did glare;
It wrung a snick, it prickled them,
And flecked the cobbler’s air.

One stab!—the spur-foil slivered through;
He twiddled, twunch, and swore;
The Awlsnarl’s shuck fell piecemeal, too;
Its eye-hole blinked no more.

“And hark!” cried all the thimble-kin,
“The stitch-room’s heart is hale!”
They braided seams with merry-grin
And hummed a trundle tale.

’Twas glimble, and the slorping burks
Did trindle in the hide;
All snorfy were the stitch-room clerks,
And frumble-tools were plied.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Desire-Path

Twas dusktime, and the gribbed green sward
Did foller-frill beneath the board;
All bramble-swish and lawn-scrawed shard
Did mutter where the footfolk trod.

"Beware the Desire-path, my son!
The wish-worn track, the short-cut run,
The sneap and snare of hurried fun
That beckons under moon and sun."

He took his blithely booted hand,
A compass clipped with tassel-band,
And peered where trodden shadows stand
To mark the crooked, whispering track.

It twined and twaggled, trim and sly,
A mump of mud, a thread of why,
A slip-sown seam 'twixt field and sty,
A crooked spine of wanton knack.

Through clover-clasp and hedge-hoot bent,
It soggled soft with footsteps spent,
It hummed of errands never meant,
Of errands cut by quickfoot whim.

He stepped—his heart a drumble-drum—
The path did pucker, pelf, and hum;
It led him where the day had come
To fold its pockets, hush the sky.

At last he stopped; the straight road glared,
A paved parade, all neat and fared;
The desire-track, with edges bared,
Sighed in the grass and waved goodbye.

Home came his father, brow unbarred,
Who chuckled at the trample-scarred;
"Well met, my son," he laughed and starred,
"Thy short-cut sings where walkers pass."

And so the field, by foot made rife,
Keeps its sly groove of human life;
A crooked hymn to hurry's knife,
The desire-path that threads our days.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about science fair in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Sciencous Fair

'Twas glimbright in the labwick hall,
And the scraggled booths did hum;
All flusterflasks and posterpalls
With gizmaglows and glum.

Beware the Quizzy-judge, my child!
The snick-snack forms are sly;
He poreth o'er your hypothesis,
With squint-licked, blinkered eye.

Heed not the Sporgle's sneer of doubt,
Nor sneb the flobber-clamp;
Stand steady, solder, stitch and shout,
Let circuits sing and lamp.

The pyrovolc and plasticgloop
Did fizz and sparr and spark;
A rover-wheeled, a light-stream loop
Did chitter in the dark.

Then from the crowd a clapper-thrum
Went sprong with tinsel-glee;
And up leapt you, all proud and plumb,
With diagram and key.

"O Frabjous Day!" the mentors cried,
"You've proved the wildest thing!"
The checkered ribbon fluttered wide—
The fair did laugh and sing.
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Dawngloom

Twas blish and breen at flumbered dawn,
When curl-thing mists did mousse and sway;
The mead was muffed, the hedgrows yawn,
And glint-crumb light was shy of day.

All purling paths in whisper-wash
Were wrapped by wool of pewter-smoke;
The river hummed a sleepy posh,
As willows winked and shiver-stroke.

Hark! the foglings, plump and sly,
Did trudge the lanes with velvet feet;
They cupped the sun, they hushed the sky,
And folded sound to softer beat.

I wandered through their gauze and gloam,
My breath a bell in milked-out air;
They braided roads into a home,
They braided hush into my hair.

Till plink of gold and sharper cheer
Unlatched the curtains of the morn;
The foglings blinked, grew thin and sheer,
And scattered like a sleep undone.

So if you meet the dawngloom near,
Be gentle with its gauze and fog;
It keeps the world both far and dear,
And lets the morning keep its smog.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Conferwocky

'Twas plooming hour, and the boardroom glimmered,
The neon hummed and the swivel-chairs skimmered;
All flimsy notes and post-it roves
Did gloop and gimbal round the glassy groves.

Beware the Zoombeast, with its pixel-eyes!
The mute-bell chortles, the echo-prise!
Beware the Slide-snout, the Stale-Phrase claw,
And steer clear of the Endless-Mumble law!

He took his laserpointer long in hand;
He sought the lectern of the Meetingland;
"Now brief! now pitch! now timebox tight!
On synergy, on timeline, on KPI-night!"

And, as he barged through the projector-mist,
The Screenbeast flickered and foggled its fist;
One stab of clarity, one crisp, bright chart —
The Slide-snout fumbled its stale, flat art.

O frabjous org! He nabbed the Action-List!
The minutes danced from the mute-thing's wrist!
He brought back consensus — not much to say —
But clearer tasks for the morrow's day.

'Twas plooming hour, and now hush hums sleek;
The coffee cools on the conference peak;
All flimsy notes and post-it roves
Do tidy tidy by the glassy groves.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about third rail hum in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Sorry — I can’t write exactly like Lewis Carroll, but here is an original poem that captures his playful nonsense and rhythmic whimsy.

The Third‑Rail Hum

Twas glim and the railwights clanked in the nithered gloom,
And the sloofish trains did snicker through tunnels of broom;
All frimsy the platforms, and brankle the drum,
When first I heard whisper the thrumming hum.

"Beware the third‑rail hum, my little chum!
Beware its fizz and the jimmer‑jolt, and shun its chromey thumb!
Beware the sparknock’s glim and the buzz that will stun —
The sly, sly, sizzlebite third‑rail hum!"

He took his lamplike lance, his coat of tar‑fringe spun,
And strode on the tiles where the moonlight was none;
He Hushled and Huffled and pricked up his ear,
For out of the shadow there came a near‑near jeer.

It buzzed and it brattled with clinkery teeth,
It hummed like a chorus of tinny bequeath;
It glarm’d and it glimmed with a fizzing thumb,
That wicked, wick‑wick, third‑rail hum.

He dodged the sizzle‑slick, he flinched from the seam,
He jumped o’er the cracklings that whispered in steam;
He wrenched his brave lamp and he waved it high,
Till the hum grew small as a sighing goodbye.

And when the hush halted and the tunnels were numb,
There grew on his lips a bright frabjous hum;
"O framp of a journey!" he laughed in the glum,
"For I have outwalked the third‑rail hum."

So mind your step where the rail‑ghosts drum,
And mind your watch for the sly, sly hum —
Lest you be toked by the sparky crumb,
Of the zizzle and buz of the third‑rail hum.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on screen burn‑in in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Burn-Glow

It was glim and the pixel-tides florr'd,
And glintle-sprites on the panel scorr'd;
Where phosphor-moss and screen-weed grew,
And stale-gleams stuck like marmaloo.

Beware the Burn-Glow, my dear, beware!
The ghostglyph clings with a sullen glare;
It lurks in corners, a stubborn sprite,
That holds old images fast as night.

He seized his rag and the scrub-sheen blade,
And danced the dithy loop, quick-made;
He swash'd the static, he scrubbed the smear,
Till after-echoes hummed and veered.

Away went ghostglyph with a sput and sigh,
Pixel-wights blinked, fled the stale-lit sky;
Yet in the silvery hush remained
A faint, fair relic—memory-stained.

O frabjous wipe! the monitors sang,
But caution twilts in the afterglow's tang;
For screens may dream what eyes have shown,
And leave soft phantoms of what was known.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Echowump of Brimway

Beneath the bridge-brow, where the dripple-ponds gleam,
A murkling wind did whiffling go;
Soft plinkled soles on the cobble-beam
Sent shimmer-tongues to and fro.

"Hearken!" cried the hollow-sly vault,
As a snorble of foot and a clankled bell
Tossed tinny tales in the tunnel's salt
Where gloam-threads curl and swell.

Out slithered the Echowump, sly and round,
All flitter-voice and mirror-mope,
It mimed each step with a muffle-sound,
And stitched each word with hope.

Plonk! went the drum of a lone dog's paw,
Skree! cried the pipe in a winkled flare;
The echo grinned in a glassy maw
And flung the noises everywhere.

It laffed the laugh that the lad had lent,
It snuck the whisper the worser said,
Till the underpass, with bright-bone bent,
Had chorus-cradled every tread.

So roam if you dare the bridge-brim gloom,
But mind the Echowump’s playful claim:
It will fetch your voice from the damp and loom
And name your name with a doubled name.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about printer jam in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Printer-Jam

’Twas inkling, and the clicksy trays
   Did whuffle in the paper-bays;
All flimsy-sheets were snug and bent,
   And spindly gears go glunk and gent.

“Beware the Printer-Jam, my friend!
   The crumple-claw, the snag-snare bend;
Its teeth are crink, its flanges pry,
   And spill the toner’s sardy sigh.”

He took his lever, cleaver-slim,
   And stalked the chute with careful vim;
The rollers hissed their muzzled-song,
   The Philips-screw did hum along.

With snip and scoot and spankish pull
   He wrestled through the fibrous hull;
The jammy-gnarl gave one last squeak,
   Then slurched away in paper-sleek.

“O frabjaw prize!” the office cried,
   As prints poured forth in flurried tide;
The idle tray resumed its hum,
   And all did dance the drum-drum-drum.

So if the whiffering gears should jam
   And make your morning go bizz-bram,
Take heart, take lever, brave and calm —
   And spare a curse for the Printer-Jam.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Twice-Glance

When glimblen dusk was whiffling o'er and curdle-light fell thin,
And brumbly-echo skittered cold along the lane again,
I walked with tumbled thimble-thought and knot of know-unseen,
For every step was mirror-stepped and every leaf had been.

Beware the Twicebeast, blinching bright, with wink-whorl eyes askew,
It hums a half-remembered hymn and hums the tune anew;
Its whisk of whisper, snap of sigh, its grin a rewound curl,
It fetches forth the impulse-ache that loops the living world.

My hand held steady, heart-sprung-sure, my courage twice-rehearsed;
A relick blade of just-since-then that trembled with the first.
"Be-gone!" I cried, "be-quieted, you echo-folly fiend!"
It answered with a soft "again" that questioned what I'd mean.

We danced the doppel-dance of dawn, we sparred with shadow-speech—
Its teeth were half my childhood's grin, its tail my twice-spent reach.
It lunged a memory into me, a moment skewed and sweet;
I struck the air; the air struck back in rhythms incomplete.

At last the Twicebeast slow-unfolded like a sigh I knew too well,
It melted into must-have-been, into the might-have-still.
I watched it fold its several selves into the one gone through,
And found the place I stood before was standing in me, too.

Now oft when glimblen dusk is low and curdle-light moves thin,
A whisper-wind repeats my step and nudges me within;
I turn and see that same same-sight, that wink-whorl eyes askew,
And hear again the Twicebeast hum, "Remember—remember you."
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about music room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Musickerwock Room

’Twas glintime in the chordy den,
and the cleffish lamps went glim;
The scale-snakes slithered on the stairs,
and faintly hummed the prim.

All atonce the metrowump
began its tickle-tock,
And brass-brook blinked its bellied gleam
upon the dusty block.

“Heark!” cried Mum of bow and reed,
“Mark well the twangfrond’s cry;
Beware the Notewump’s hollow hum,
and shun the Skirl-snap sly;

For though the fretlick’s fiddlers fine
with arpeggloos may dance,
The Snaregroove’s teeth will clatter-rend
if you misstrike its glance.”

With baton bright and foot a-thrum,
a player strode within;
He swung the stave-sword, plucked the air,
and tuned the whispering din.

Then burst the brasslehorn’s brazen bell,
the piano’s pawing keys;
A cyclerium of cymballed birds
tore through the raftry breeze.

He struck a chord, the room replied
in shiver-sigh and bloom;
The Notewump folded, note by note,
and hush’d the metrowoom.

Now silence laced the lamp-glow thin,
and motes in measures swam;
The Musickerwock Room kept its breath
—soft as a softened damn.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about layover bay in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Layover-Bay

Twas whisking, and the gate-lit halls were brim,
The tarmacs snuffled in their sleep;
All clammy clocks with yawned-out rims
Tick-tockled where the travelers keep.

Beware the Layover-Bay, my friend!
Beware its jostle-jaw and queue;
The delaywurm with luggage-hands,
The stroller-gnarls that stick like glue.

He took his glinting pass in paw;
Long shone the barcode, bright and thin;
He paced the plexi-plaza floor,
And hummed his hums to stave the din.

And, as he shifted by Gate Gree,
There slouched the traybore, flump and wide;
It burbled through the carousel
And snuffled at the coffee-side.

One swipe! One beep! The pass did flash—
It snicked the traybore’s sullen snoot;
It toppled from the carousel,
Its suitcase-tangle all a-sloot.

"O blithely-bayed!" the people cried,
"O snug-sit, smooth and restful stay!"
They folded maps and nestled down
And hailed the calm of Layover-Bay.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Conferencewocky

Twas board-time, and the clipper-flats did gleam,
The screenage glowéd, and the swivel-chairs did stream;
All mimsy were the coffee-cups and splotch,
And the whiteboard shadows scribbled blorpy scotch.

"Beware the Slidesnark, my colleague! The mute-tinge!
The PowerPointwock, with its endless bulge and hinge!
Beware the Blurb-bomb that doth loop and drone,
And the dreaded Time-suck that eats the hourstone!"

He took his laser-spear in hand; long-click and brave,
And sought the dim-lit table where the Meeting-Maws behave;
Through carpet-gnarl and hallway-hum he strode,
Past the sticky-note groves where the agenda-thickets growed.

And, as in fog the projector's beam did skirl,
Came the Slidesnark whiffling with a fusty whirl;
One, two! One, two! And through the slideshowed fray
He jabbed the laser; the mute-tinge shrank away.

He left it dead, the Slidesnark lay serene,
He logged it off, and closed the tab unseen;
And, with a corkscrew grin, he sipped his cooling brew,
While the clock-gnomes ticked the minutes softly through.

"O frabjous day! Call-break and coffee-boon!"
He chortled by the window of the noon;
Yet still the warning hums in conference-room gloom:
Beware the Slidesnark when thou next enter a Zoom.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Beware the Awl

Twas tangle-twilit, brim and brast,
The leather-larks were low;
All stitchlings snuffed the hemming-blast
Beneath the ferrum-glow.

"Beware the Awl, my lad," they cried,
"The awl with spindled fang;
It skitter-pokes where seams abide,
And makes the tender sang."

He took his vorpal awl in hand,
Long-spit and keen of spine;
Through buckle-bruin, strap and band
He stooped the bristled line.

One jab! — the awl went snick and true,
The hide gave yelp and seam;
He wrenched it out with froth and dew,
Then stitched the renting gleam.

"O hast thou mended, stitcher-soul?"
The cobble-wrens replied;
Now brad and buckle bless the toll,
And snug the welted hide.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Creep of Slumberdell

Twas glim and glower in Slumberdell glade,
When bristle-fog dripped from the moon's half-bowl;
The snatch-sprites hushed in the mossy shade,
And the willow-winks winked on the knurl-roots' knoll.

"Hark!" crooned mother with tremble-tongue thin,
"Beware the creep that crawls the low-glee;
With slither-sneer and a whispering grin,
It skims the gloom like a sighing sea.

"It has blinked-black eyes and a feathered hush-foot,
A hunch of shadow and claws of rime;
It gathers the hush in its silky soot,
And counts your breaths like a chiming time."

So forth went Boldling with brace-heart high,
Girt with a glimmer-glaive o'er his hip;
He hummed a throstle-chant to the night-sky,
And stepped through the fern-foam's drip and slip.

There in the fen where the marsh-motes sweep,
The Creep uncoiled with a lilted leer;
Its velvet-threads hummed a lullaby deep,
Its tail-tips tinkled like tear-glass near.

They met with a swish, a snarble, a snap,
The glimmer-glaive sung, the dark-threads flared;
The Creep gave a croon like a twilit trap,
And the bramble-bones shivered and cowered and dared.

With a twist and a twine and a bright, quick cleft,
Boldling struck where the night was most thin;
The Creep unspooled and the hush was left—
A tuft of dusk and a rueful grin.

Home came the lad with the hush in a jar,
The moon-beads bobbed on the cottage sill;
And mother placed it on the sill so far,
Singing, "Mind the creep, and heed your will."

For the Creep may slumber or curl and sleep,
But slumbered things wake at a careless peep;
So fold your doors and your laughter keep,
And never feed dark with a careless leap.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Desire-Path

In gloam-swish hours of murk and moon,
When bramble-blep and brastles croon,
The ground did gurgle, rootlets snatch,
And bent the hedges’ mossy latch.

Beware the Desire-path, O child!
The shortcut sings in whisper-wild:
It twists in glint and grit-sheen loops,
And hems the world with secret scoops.

He strode with bootles, heart allthrum,
Past hedgerow-hush and thistle-sum,
Where foot-folk left their slip-worn seam
Of squelch and sparkle, thread of dream.

The path it wove, a sneer-sweet track,
With sidle-sigh and knucklebark crack;
It taught his feet to flint and fly,
To faun the rules, to wink and why.

He followed, follow, farther bent,
Through broke-sod years and comet-scent;
Till at the bend, mid hush and humm,
A glim-thing twitched its velvet drum.

“Come, stride,” it crooned, “you wayward toe,
Where beaten-breezes softly blow;
Skirt fences, maps, and planful craft,
And stitch the world with single draft.”

He lunged a laugh, he leapt a lark,
He stamped a path through dim and dark;
No snicker-snap of rule nor scorn
Could turn the thread that feet had worn.

So now the fields are filigree
Of human-jigs and compass-plea;
The Desire-path, sly and true,
Still hums the road our soles hew through.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fogmire

Dawn was drimbled, and the glum-gull gray
Slubbled slow on lane and leen;
The shutters clucked, the hedges sway,
And roofs put on their drowsey sheen.

Out from whorls a mizzle-wrack
Skittered with its whisper-woe,
A fogmote with a fluffling back,
And eyes like teacups, dimly aglow.

It slurped the signposts, lapped the lane,
It twinked the bell with muffled thrum;
The clapper-birds went blur and plain,
As cobbles yawned and curtains numb.

Then sunspine pried its honey-knives
And plaited gold through mist and murk;
The fogmote sighed its silver lives
And folded up its smoke-silk work.

Now lanes lie clean as kettle-song,
The morn walks light on dew-slick toes;
But if you wake before things throng,
You’ll catch the fogmire’s gentle doze.
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on film camera in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Shutterwock

Twas filmig, and the sprocky spools
Did gindle in the gloam and glass;
All mimsy lenses leapt in fools,
And wickled light through brass and brass.

"Beware the Shutterwock, my lad!
The click-claw'd beast with flashfang bright;
Beware the Lensly Lash, so mad!
Beware the sprocket-snarl by night!"

He took his hand upon the grip,
He cocked the bolt and wound the skein;
He peered through viewfinder's tight-lip,
And felt the film-heart drum and strain.

One, two! The shutter snicked with bite,
He clicked—away! The exposure fled;
The emulsy night caught slivers of light,
And left its ghosts on silver thread.

The Shutterwock did bleat and blaze,
Its flash-rows fanged the air with bloom;
But tripod-sabre, steady, stays,
And brackets buckled crack the gloom.

He spooled it home, the negative,
With whisper-keys and fixer-song;
The darkroom hummed with chemistry's hive,
And stains of halation thronged.

"O frabjous frame!" He chortled, "Brave!"
He clacked the contact, smug and small;
The grainy dreams from reel to wave
Hung drying, feathered on the wall.

Twas filmig, and the sprocky spools
Still gindled in the gloam and glass;
All mimsy lenses counted fools,
And light went clicking—slowly—past.
label: high
